title: Question 129

children: A 53-year-old woman is evaluated for an acute, slightly pruritic rash over her legs. She also has chronic venous insufficiency.

On physical examination, she is afebrile. In addition to typical changes of chronic venous insufficiency, lower extremity examination shows bilateral eczematous patches with redness, weeping, and in some areas, scaling, most prominent over the medial aspect of the leg.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Stasis dermatitis is a complication of chronic venous insufficiency, which is recognized by the presence of dependent edema, varicose veins, and trophic skin changes such as hyperpigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis, and ulcers.
Stasis dermatitis is an inflammatory reaction that can be very pruritic and erythematous and may include vesiculation and weeping skin.

). Stasis dermatitis is a complication of chronic venous insufficiency, which is recognized by the presence of dependent edema, varicose veins, and trophic skin changes such as hyperpigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis, and ulcers. Stasis dermatitis is an inflammatory reaction that can be very pruritic and erythematous and may include vesiculation and weeping skin. Symptoms are often bilateral, although it may be unilaterally symptomatic. Treatment typically includes exercise (walking or heel lifts) and compression stockings to decrease venous hypertension and dependent edema.

The presence of fever, lymphadenopathy, or other evidence of infection, such as an elevated leukocyte count, also would suggest this diagnosis. It is important to consider alternative diagnoses when there are erythematous patches on both legs.

) is a condition caused by repetitive scratching or rubbing. Predisposing conditions include atopic dermatitis, xerosis, and psychiatric conditions such as obsessive-compulsive disorder. Lichen simplex chronicus manifests as thickened plaques with erythema and hyperpigmentation. Exaggerated skin markings are seen on the surface of the skin as well. Common sites include the genitals, back of the neck, wrists, ankles, and lower legs. Lichen simplex chronicus does not present as an acute eczematous skin reaction with weeping associated with chronic venous insufficiency.
